Description: Shoulder sherd of East Greek, probably Clazomenian, pottery neck amphora; exterior: glazed black around plastic fillet at junction of neck and shoulder; below, painted decoration consisting of five rows of scales with dots in added white at centre of each scale; inside reserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Cook states that although the scales are typical of Clazomenian black figure pottery, they are not exclusive to Clazomenian pottery and therefore, the origin of this specific sherd cannot be confirmed although Clazomenian scales tend to be long (Cook 1952, 143, n. 102, no. 7). For parallels regarding the shape and decoration, see Heidelberg I29.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 143 note 102, no. 5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.129) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
